attributes.title: Reward Loops
attributes.description: All files related to the 'Reward loops' paper

q1.value: Effect of daily life reward loop functioning on the course of depression

q2.value: Daan Alexander Ornee, Albertine Oldehinkel, Jojanneke A. Bastiaansen

q3.value:
Loss of pleasure or anhedonia is one of the core symptoms of depression. It describes the diminished ability to enjoy (daily) life, and has been associated with both the development and maintenance of depression (Pizzagalli, 2014; Spijker et al., 2001; Wardenaar et al., 2012). Pleasure can be subdivided into three separate components: wanting, liking and learning (Berridge et al., 2009; Berridge & Robinson, 2003). Each component describes a separate aspect of an evolutionary adaptive reward loop intended to steer us towards rewards, either tangible (e.g. food, warmth) or more abstract (e.g. praise, accomplishments). Evidence from neurobiological and experimental research in laboratory settings shows that the temporal relations in this reward loop are disturbed in people suffering from depressive symptoms (Berridge & Kringelbach, 2015; Vrieze et al., 2013; Whitton et al., 2015). To investigate reward loops in daily life, recent studies employed Ecological Momentary Assessment (EMA), a measurement approach in which participants receive multiple short questionnaires per day over the course of several days or weeks (Heininga et al., 2017; van Roekel et al., 2019; Wichers et al., 2015). An EMA study by Bakker et al. (2017) indicated that the disturbances in the reward loop as found in neurobiological studies can also be detected in daily life. 
 	Although deficits in reward loops have repeatedly been associated with depressive symptoms, the influence of reward loop functioning on the course of depression remains largely untested. Berridge and Robinson (2003) assumed that strong reward loop connections are adaptive in the sense that they steer an organism towards rewards. Behavioral activation, an effective treatment for depression (Dimidjian et al., 2011; Lewinsohn, 1974), also builds on this assumption: engaging in activities increase the chances of positive experiences, which subsequently reinforces future motivation for engaging in activities. Conversely, in a poorly connected reward loop increasing e.g. motivation through therapy would be ineffective as there would be no influence on subsequent engagement in activities. In other words; a functioning reward loop should contribute to recovery from depression.

q4.value: Higher reward loop connection strength is associated with decreases in depressive symptoms over time.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: TThe current study has a repeated measures design, and uses data from the Do-module  treatment arm of the ZELF-i study. The ZELF-i study is a pragmatic multi-site randomized controlled trial (RCT) with participants starting treatment for depressive symptoms aged between 18 and 65 years. Participants allocated to the Do-module engaged in 28 days of EMA (5 times per day) and received weekly personalized feedback on positive affect and activities. For more details on the ZELF-i study, see the protocol paper, available online: https://doi.org/10.1186/s12888-018-1847-z.

q9.value: Not applicable to the current study. For randomization procedures of the ZELF-i trial see Bastiaansen et al. (2018).

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value:
Data has already been collected because participants were part of the ZELF-i study for which data was collected between 2016 and 2019. No study using ZELF-i data has examined the research questions of the current study. 

Prior knowledge of current dataset: 
Two of the authors of the current study (DO, JAB) were involved in large parts of the ZELF-i data collection. In addition, the ZELF-i data has been used in two prior studies investigating the effects of treatment group on momentary affect (pre-print available online: https://doi.org/10.31234/osf.io/gub36) and on depressive symptoms, empowerment and social functioning over time (pre-registration available online: https://osf.io/2c9ak). As a result we have knowledge of the data regarding momentary affect and depressive symptom trajectories, both on the group and person level. . However, the other measures used to construct the reward loops have not been analyzed or investigated before, and we have no prior knowledge of the data regarding the predictive value of such reward loops on depressive symptom levels. Furthermore, the study on momentary affect analyzed the individual trajectories of momentary affect; in this study we investigate the temporal moment-to-moment relations between the included variables as a measure of reward loop strength, which has not been investigated previously in this data.

question.value: Sampling and data collection procedures: See protocol paper (Bastiaansen et al., 2018). Participant inclusion was finished when at least 40 participants in each of the three conditions (Control, Do, Think) completed both the baseline (T0) and post-intervention measurement (T1), and, for the treatment arms, also completed the intervention (no drop-out). The total number of included participants is 161 (55 Do, 55 Think, 51 Control). In the current study, only the participants in the Do module (55 participants) will be used.

q13.value: After removing 7 drop-outs we will include 48 participants who completed the 'Do' module of the ZELF-i study. Each participant received a total of 140 diaries, across 28 days (5x each day). The first day of measurements will be excluded to reduce the Initial Elevation Bias (Shrout et al., 2018). All individual measurements starting from the second day of measuring that were completed within a half-hour window will be taken as valid measurements. Any measurements recorded after half an hour since questionnaire opening will be excluded from further analysis.

q14.value:
Since no new data was collected we cannot influence the sample size.
We used G*power 3.1.9.4 (Faul et al., 2007) to determine the effect size we are able to detect with 80% power. As G*power does not provide methods for power calculation in our multilevel structure we approximated our design using the ANOVA: repeated measures, within factor command. In this command a single correlation between repeated measures needs to be provided. There is no consensus on how to best calculate a single correlation unit, therefore we provide the detectable effect sizes for our lowest and highest found correlation between repeated measures. Furthermore, we used a Fisher-Z transformation to calculate the mean correlation, which was then transformed back to a regular correlation (code available online: https://osf.io/peq7r/). Given the sample size, six repeated measures and correlations of 0.36, 0.72 and 0.91 among the repeated measures we have 80% power to detect effect sizes 0.17, 0.11 and 0.06 respectively.

q15.value: Not applicable for the current study since no new data was collected

question.value: Not applicable for the current study

All EMA variables were measured at each timepoint, on visual analogue scales ranging from 'not/not at all' (0) to 'all the time/very much' (100). The order of all questions was fixed, for a detailed view of all questions and sequence, see table 1 in Bastiaansen et al., 2018 (https://doi.org/10.1186/s12888-018-1847-z). See Figure 1 for a schematic overview of the measured variables and indices. 

Engagement in activities is operationalized as activities or active behavior leading to rewarding experiences, either physically or psychologically. During each measurement, participants were asked for the previous three hours (retrospective) to respond to the statements "I've been physically active", "I've been in pleasant company" and "I did what I wanted to". For each person and each timepoint, the  average score of the three questions will be taken as an indication of amount of engagement in activities in the preceding timeslot. 

Positive Experiences reflects the amount of positive affect (PA) participants experience at the time of measurement (momentary). Participants entered responses to “Right now, I feel...” on emotional adjectives, balanced on the arousal dimension (high/low) of emotional experience. PA was measured with the adjectives cheerful, relaxed, satisfied, energetic, enthusiastic and calm (e.g. “I feel cheerful”). Similar to other studies in the field (see for example Brans, Koval, Verduyn, Lim, & Kuppens, 2013; Hartmann et al., 2015; Verhagen, Simons, van Zelst, & Delespaul, 2017) a single positive affect score will be calculated as the mean score of the six positive adjectives for each person at each measurement. 

For Motivation participants were asked to think about the next three hours (prospective), or the next day in case of the last diary of the day. Participants responded to the statements "I intend to undertake certain things" and "I'm looking forward to the next three hours/day". The composite measure of motivation will be calculated as the average of the two items for each person at each measurement. 

Depression severity was measured with the total score of the 30-item self-report Inventory of Depressive Symptomatology (IDS-SR) (Rush, Gullion, Basco, Jarrett, & Trivedi, 1996) across 6 time points: at baseline, after 4 weeks of ESM and at 4 follow-up measurements at 1, 2, 3, and 6 months post-ESM. The IDS-SR includes all DSM-IV diagnostic criterion items for major depressive disorder, as well as commonly associated symptoms such as irritability. Each symptom item is scored on a scale from 0 to 3, with higher scores denoting greater symptom severity. The IDS-SR has good psychometric properties with high concurrent and internal validity (Cronbach’s α = .92)

The analysis consist of two parts: the construction of the reward loops (1) and the repeated measures analysis on the course of depressive symptoms (2). All analyses will be performed using the lme4 package (Bates et al., 2015, p. 4) in R (R Core Team, 2019). p-values will be obtained using lmerTest (Kuznetsova et al., 2017).

(1) Reward loops 
First, we investigate the overall reward loop structure for the whole sample by performing multilevel linear regression analyses, taking into account that the daily diary measurements (level 1) are nested within persons (level 2). Each node in the reward loop will be used as dependent variable in the regression analyses once, with the lagged preceding node as predictor. To control for autocorrelation, the lagged version of the dependent variable will be added as a covariate. Random intercepts and slopes will be added to allow participants to vary independently, leading to the following regression equations:

-	Motivation(t) = Positive Experiences(t) + Motivation(t-1) 
-	Engagement in Activities(t) = Motivation(t-1) + Engagement in Activities(t-1)
-	Positive Experiences(t) = Engagement in Activities(t) + Positive Experiences(t-1)

Furthermore, the last Motivation measurement of the day will not be allowed to predict the first Engagement in Activities of the day to prevent unequal timespacing. The model will be fitted using restricted maximum likelihood estimation, which can handle missing data well, and correlated random slopes and intercepts. As indication of the random effects the variance of both intercept and slope will be reported. Any nonconvergence of one of the regression analyses due to low levels of variation of the items will be interpreted as a sign of absent connection strength for that path, which will then be set to zero. Subsequently, we will average the three standardized pathway coefficients for each individual as a measure of reward loop strength, resulting in a single average standardized coefficient for each participant. 

(2) Reward loop strength & depressive symptoms 
To investigate the influence of reward loop strength on depressive symptoms over 6 months, we will perform a multilevel linear regression analysis with reward loop strength as predictor and depressive symptoms level over time as dependent variable. The model will again be fitted using restricted maximum likelihood estimation and correlated random slopes and intercepts. As indication of the random effects the variance of both intercept and slope will be reported.

q21.value: p-values will be set at alpha = 0.05.

q23.value: Restricted maximum likelihood estimation (REML) can deal with missing data well. No further missing data treatments will be used.

First, we investigate the overall reward loop structure for the whole sample by performing multilevel linear regression analyses, taking into account that the daily diary measurements (level 1) are nested within persons (level 2). Each node in the reward loop will be used as dependent variable in the regression analyses once, with the lagged preceding node as predictor. To control for autocorrelation, the lagged version of the dependent variable will be added as a covariate. Random intercepts and slopes will be added to allow participants to vary independently, leading to the following regression equations:

-	Motivation(t) = Positive Experiences(t) + Motivation(t-1) 
-	Engagement in Activities(t) = Motivation(t-1) + Engagement in Activities(t-1)
-	Positive Experiences(t) = Engagement in Activities(t) + Positive Experiences(t-1)

Furthermore, the last Motivation measurement of the day will not be allowed to predict the first Engagement in Activities of the day to prevent unequal timespacing. The model will be fitted using restricted maximum likelihood estimation, which can handle missing data well, and correlated random slopes and intercepts. As indication of the random effects the variance of both intercept and slope will be reported. Any nonconvergence of one of the regression analyses due to low levels of variation of the items will be interpreted as a sign of absent connection strength for that path, which will then be set to zero. Subsequently, we will average the three standardized pathway coefficients for each individual as a measure of reward loop strength, resulting in a single average standardized coefficient for each participant. 

(2) Reward loop strength & depressive symptoms 
To investigate the influence of reward loop strength on depressive symptoms over 6 months, we will perform a multilevel linear regression analysis with reward loop strength as predictor and depressive symptoms level over time as dependent variable. The model will again be fitted using restricted maximum likelihood estimation and correlated random slopes and intercepts. As indication of the random effects the variance of both intercept and slope will be reported.

attributes.title: ACES and Suicidal Thoughts/Attempts among Utahns: BRFSS

summary.value:
This preregistration contains a brief description of what we will be examining, our research questions, hypotheses, and a basic outline of our analytical plan. 

Description of the study: In the state of Utah there is a growing conversation about suicide and suicide prevention. One of the major concerns of the state is the prevalence of suicidal thoughts and attempts among sexual minority Utahns. In a previous project, we used the 2016 and 2017 datasets from Utah's Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS), a large population-estimated sample, in order to report on the prevalence of suicidal/self-harming thoughts and the lifetime prevalence of suicidal attempts among LGB and Heterosexual Utahns. LGB adult Utahns, when compared to heterosexuals, were drastically more likely to report recent suicidal/self-harming thoughts (14.3% vs. 4.3%; X2(1) = 14,651.00, p < .001; OR = 3.71 (95% CI [3.63, 3.80]) and lifetime prevalence of suicide attempts (36.6% vs. 7.0%; X2(1) = 172,602.82, p < .001; OR = 7.66 (95% CI [7.57,7.74]). Of even greater concern, was that LGB Utahns were more than 12 times more likely to report multiple suicide attempts than heterosexual Utahns (26.5% vs. 2.8%; difference = 23.7%, 95% CI [18.24, 29.98]); X2(1) = 360.79, p < .001, OR = 12.49 (95% CI [8.99, 17.35]). Thus, LGB Utahns may be nearly three times more likely to attempt suicide than other LGB adults in population samples (e.g., Hottes, et al., 2016). 

Moving beyond reporting on the prevalence, we now seek to explore potential predictors of suicidal/self-harming thoughts and suicide attempts among LGB and Heterosexual Utahns. Both the 2016 and 2018 Utah BRFSS datasets included items on adverse childhood experience (ACEs) and the respective suicide variables. As such we sought to answer and test the following research questions and hypotheses: 

Research Questions:

RQ1: What is the prevalence of ACEs, suicidal thoughts, and attempts among LGB and heterosexual Utahns?
RQ2: Are certain types of ACEs (e.g., sexual abuse) stronger predictors of suicidal variables? 
RQ3: Is there a moderation effect of sexual orientation between ACEs and suicidal variables?
RQ4: How might the dose effect of ACEs affect Utahns’ suicidality by sexual orientation? 

Hypotheses:

H1: LGB participants are will report higher levels of total ACEs, sexual abuse, physical abuse, witnessing domestic violence, and troubled homes, than heterosexual participants. 
H1a: LGB participants will be more likely to report 7 or more ACEs, than heterosexual participants.
H1b: Bisexual participants will be more likely to report total ACEs, sexual abuse, physical abuse, witnessing domestic violence, and troubled homes, than LG participants.
H2: LGB participants will report higher prevalence lifetime prevalence of suicide attempts, than heterosexual participants.
H2a: Bisexual participants will report higher prevalence lifetime prevalence of suicide attempts, than LG participants. 
H3: Total ACEs will predict frequency of recent (two weeks) suicidal/self-harming thoughts, above and beyond controls.
H3a: There will be a dose effect with higher levels of ACES having a larger effect on frequency of recent (two weeks) suicidal/self-harming thoughts. 
H3b: Sexual abuse will predict frequency of recent (two weeks) suicidal/self-harming thoughts, above and beyond all other ACEs.
H4: Total ACEs will predict any lifetime suicide attempt, above and beyond controls.
H4a: Total ACEs will predict multiple lifetime suicide attempts, above and beyond controls.
 H4b: There will be a dose effect with higher levels of ACE having a larger effect on any lifetime suicide attempts.
H4c: There will be a dose effect with higher levels of ACE having a larger effect on multiple  lifetime suicide attempts.
H4d: Sexual abuse will predict lifetime prevalence of suicide attempts, above and beyond all other ACEs.
H5: Sexual orientation will moderate the relationship between total ACEs frequency of recent (two weeks) suicidal/self-harming thoughts, any suicide attempt, and multiple lifetime suicide attempts.
H5a: Sexual orientation will also moderate the dosing effect between higher levels of ACEs and recent (two weeks) suicidal/self-harming thoughts, any suicide attempt, and multiple lifetime suicide attempts.

Analytical plan:

Preliminary
- Weighting variable
- Create the dichotomous variables 
- Basic descriptives (pre/post weighting and imputations) 
- Frequency, distributions, missingness (missing completely random), Mean, SD, etc. 
- Choose a plan for missingness (e.g., multiple imputations, MLM, FIML). 

Inferential
- T Test/Mann Whitney U. 
- Chi-squared
- Regression
- Logistic, count, interaction terms.

q1.value: Evaluations of postoperative transitions in care for older adults

q3.value: Older adults have surgery at a higher rate than any other age group. Older adults are at risk of poor outcomes after surgery, including increased time in hospital, complications, worsened disability, and difficulty living independently at home. These increased risks also result in higher costs to the healthcare system. The transition out of hospital is a particularly vulnerable time for older adults and their caregivers. To develop and test new interventions to better support people with frailty transitioning out of hospital after surgery, we must first understand what a successful transition in care means to older adults and their caregivers. To address this knowledge gap, we will first summarize how researchers currently evaluate successful transitions in care for older adults leaving hospital by reviewing and synthesizing the scientific literature. Synthesizing current literature will provide us with an opportunity to determine the extent to which current research aligns with patient values and priorities.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Scoping Review

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
A comprehensive search strategy will be developed with a research librarian. We will apply it to the databases; Medline (Ovid), EMBASE (Ovid), CINHAL, and Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL). The searches in the electronic databases will be carried out from their respective inception dates to October 3, 2019. Reference lists and grey literature will be examined. Abstracts will also be included as they should detail primary outcomes. The literature search will not impose language or date restrictions. 

Study Selection: Titles and abstracts will be screened using a liberal accelerated approach. To ensure that all studies are screened in duplicate, all abstracts that are identified as an exclusion will be reviewed by a second reviewer. Next, full texts will be reviewed in duplicate followed by data extraction. Disagreements will be resolved through consensus. 

Data will be extracted independently by two authors using a pre-piloted data charting form. Investigators will ensure their extraction is consistent and aligned with the research question. Charting will be iterative and the form will be updated with continuous data extraction.

attributes.title: Do images with negative emotional valence affect memory formation for a preceding image?

item1.value: This preregistration concerns a replication study for an as-of-yet unpublished experiment conducted by Schwensfeier, Kandemir, and Nieuwenstein. In this unpublished experiment, we examined how memory for an image of an object (T1) is affected when it is followed within 300 or 1000 ms by an image depicting either negative or neutral contents (T2). To ensure the processing of the emotional or neutral contents of T2, participants performed a speeded 2-alternative forced choice task (2-AFC) requiring a judgment of whether the contents of T2 were negative or neutral. The results showed that a neutral T2 interfered with memory for T1 when it was shown at a stimulus onset asynchrony (SOA) of 300 ms, but not when it was shown at an SOA of 1000 ms, thus replicating earlier findings showing that the process of consolidating a stimulus into working memory can be disrupted by a speeded 2-AFC task (Nieuwenstein & Wyble, 2014; see also, Kandemir, Akyürek, & Nieuwenstein, 2017). Interestingly, a different pattern was found for negative T2 images: Compared to neutral T2s, negative T2s interfered equally with memory for T1 at the SOA of 300 ms, but they differed in also producing significant interference at an SOA of 1000 ms. This finding suggests that negative emotional images not only disrupt consolidation but also maintenance of information in working memory. The primary aim of the study preregistered in this report is to test the replicability of this finding. In addition, the preregistered study will expand on the original study by also including two shorter SOAs, of 100 and 200 ms, to examine how neutral and negative images affect T1 processing at these very early time points.

item2.value: The outcome of the unpublished experiment was unexpected and of interest for theories about how emotional stimuli may impact memory for temporally contiguous neutral stimuli.

item12.value: In a room next to the cabins in which participants perform the experiment

item13.value: Complete: It is a within-subjects design.

item14.value: Complete: We conducted the original study ourselves and now intend to see if we can replicate the outcomes.

item24.value: The replication study includes 4 levels of one the stimulus onset asynchrony (SOA: 100, 200, 300 and 1000 ms). The original study included only 2 levels (300 and 1000). Additional levels are included to enable an exploration of what happens at earlier SOAs.

item25.value: Previous findings do not suggest that including additional levels of SOA will alter the outcome for the SOAs included in the original experiment.

item26.value: Accuracy below chance on first or second target is a reason to remove a participant. We will also perform an outlier exclusion procedure on reaction times for the second task, using the procedure described by Van Selst and Jolicoeur (1994).

item27.value: Firstly, we will conduct the exact same analyses as in the original study. These analyses are at the center of this preregistration, as they are intended as confirmatory analyses for the outcomes of our original experiment. In addition, we will conduct additional analyses to explore the data further.

item28.value: Replication of the original outcomes for SOAs of 300 and 1000 ms. This outcome comprised two interaction effects observed in specific contrasts: An interaction of SOA and T2 condition (Absent vs. Neutral) and an interaction of SOA and T2 condition (Neutral vs. Negative).

attributes.title: Consumer Effort and Learning in DIY Domains

q1.value: DIY Excel Study - Learning Intervention (UNL Lab March 2020)

q3.value:
We have demonstrated that consumers are less satisfied with firm-provided offerings when they have exerted lower effort on the task prior to the firm's solution. We are attempting to replicate this finding in a lab setting using a paradigm that has led us to observe our expected effects in the past. In addition to replicating prior findings, we are also incorporating a learning intervention condition in which we propose the firm can attenuate dissatisfaction by educating the consumer about the task and its solution during the customer-firm interaction. Our study also examines customer mindset (fixed vs. growth). We have consistently found our focal effects for those with more growth-minded views, but not fixed-minded views. Thus, in this study, we are planning to manipulate all participants into a growth mindset. 

In this study, we plan to have participants complete a difficult task in Excel, but have the opportunity to "pay" a teaching assistant to help them complete the task. To ensure interactions with the TA occur, participants will not be able to advance in the survey without completing the task. Our focal independent variable is the amount of time participants spend working on the task prior to soliciting help from the TA. Our focal DV is their satisfaction with the services provided by the TA. We will also be manipulating participants into a growth mindset prior to this interaction.

q4.value: For growth-minded consumers, there will be an interaction between effort spent on the task and the service interaction type. Those who exert less effort on the task (-1SD) will be less satisfied when they experience a standard interaction (control condition), relative to when they experience the learning intervention interaction. We do not expect satisfaction to differ between conditions for those who exert higher effort (+1SD). Lastly, we expect this interaction to be mediated by perceived learning.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q7.value: The teaching assistant who will be helping students with the task will know which condition the participant has been assigned to. However, this individual is not affiliated with this research project and is blind to the research hypotheses and prior findings.

question.value:
This is a 2-condition between subjects design. PArticipants will be assigned to either experience a standard interaction with the teaching assistant or will experience a learning-based interaction designed to educate the participant about the task they were asked to complete. Our other focal IV will be a measured variable--time spent working on the task prior to asking the TA for help. 

We note that we are purposely manipulating all participants into a growth mindset for this study. We are not testing this mindset relative to a fixed mindset--we do not have a fixed mindset condition.

q9.value: Randomization will be conducted by Qualtrics at the outset of the survey.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We are using a pre-existing participant pool from our college of business. These students volunteer for participation in lab activities in exchange for extra course credit. They are recruited through both email communications and announcements made in class by their professors. All students who are eligible for the pool will be eligible for the study. We will be excluding participants who are able to successfully finish the Excel task, as those students will not require the services of the teaching assistant.

q14.value: We are limited to the number of students who volunteer to participate in the session.

q15.value: We will terminate data collection when the lab session ends.

question.value: Service Interaction (Learning condition vs. control)

Satisfaction with the teaching assistant's services
Likelihood to use the TA's help with future Excel problems
Effort spent on the task
Mindset (manipulation check)
Perceived learning
Experience with Excel
Prior experience with the VLookup function of Excel
Gender
Age
All multi-item scales will be averaged to create mean scores for the variables above. Time spent on the task will be measured using Qualtrics' timing function.

We will use regression to test the predicted interaction. Simple contrasts will be used to examine the differences between conditions for those who spend higher (+1SD) and lower (-1SD) time on the task. This will be done by recentering the effort variable at these levels and recalculating the regression. We will test for mediation through perceived learning using Hayes' PROCESS macro model 8.

q20.value: Depending on the distribution of the time variable, it may be necessary to log-transform the variable. This measure will also be mean-centered for the analysis. The experimental conditions will be binary coded (learning = 1, control = -1).

q21.value: Cutoff criteria for significance will be p<.05. If the p-value is between .05 and .10, marginal significance will be reported. We will also be reporting effect sizes.

q22.value: Participants will be removed if they successfully complete the task. These are the only exclusions that will occur.

q23.value: Cases with missing data will be omitted from the analysis.

q25.value: As noted, we are planning to prime ALL participants into a growth mindset. This is because prior findings have indicated that our focal effect is not observed for fixed-minded participants. Our goal for this study is to examine the effectiveness of the learning intervention on consumer evaluations in attenuating our previously identified effect. Because of expected sample size limitations, we will be unable to test the full factorial design including fixed mindset (because no effect is expected there based on prior observations). Thus, for these two reasons, this study will only be looking at the growth mindset condition (in prior studies we have manipulated both).

These students volunteer for participation in lab activities in exchange for extra course credit. They are recruited through both email communications and announcements made in class by their professors. All students who are eligible for the pool will be eligible for the study. We will be excluding participants who are able to successfully finish the Excel task, as those students will not require the services of the teaching assistant.
registration_responses.q16.question: Service Interaction (Learning condition vs. control)
registration_responses.q17.question:
Satisfaction with the teaching assistant's services
Likelihood to use the TA's help with future Excel problems
Effort spent on the task
Mindset (manipulation check)
Perceived learning
Experience with Excel
Prior experience with the VLookup function of Excel
Gender
Age
registration_responses.q18.question: All multi-item scales will be averaged to create mean scores for the variables above. Time spent on the task will be measured using Qualtrics' timing function.
registration_responses.q19.question: We will use regression to test the predicted interaction. Simple contrasts will be used to examine the differences between conditions for those who spend higher (+1SD) and lower (-1SD) time on the task. This will be done by recentering the effort variable at these levels and recalculating the regression. We will test for mediation through perceived learning using Hayes' PROCESS macro model 8.

attributes.title: Does personality affect mental health through health behaviors and inflammation?
attributes.description: This projects looks at the relationship between personality and mental health through the lens of health behaviors and inflammation.

q1.value: Does personality affect mental health through behaviors and inflammation?

q2.value: Samuel Ryan Stevens Adcock, Sara J. Weston

q3.value: The relationship between personality and mental health could have a number of factors that play a role. We want to look at how inflammation and health behaviors such as drinking, smoking, and physical activity influence the relationship between personality and mental health.

q4.value:
1. There will be a direct effect of Conscientiousness and Neuroticism on mental health and an indirect effect of Conscientiousness and Neuroticism on mental health through health behaviors and inflammation.
2. The theoretical path model is the best fit for the data.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The Health and Retirement Study assesses personality every 4 years and health behaviors every two years. Biomarker data has been collected from subsets of the full sample every two years. All information is self-report, with the exception of the biomarker data. Full documentation regarding sampling of participants and survey administration is available at http://hrs.isr.umich.edu/

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value:
The first author, SA, has no previous knowledge of the HRS dataset and has not access the data at this point. All analyses are based on understanding from the literature. It should be noted, however, that some of the material covered in the literature review used the Health and Retirement Study as the source of data, and so these theories and hypotheses cannot be extricated from the data itself.

The senior author, SW, has extensive knowledge of the dataset. This author has not contributed to major analytic decisions but has guided the choice of how to test specific hypotheses generated by the first author. It should be noted that all analyses were planned with the expectation that a different dataset would be used and due to last-minute restrictions, these analyses were adjusted to be tested using the HRS. The senior author will list publications based on the HRS in this OSF project after peer review.

question.value: Data have been collected by researchers at the University of Michigan with a collection of phone-interviews, self-report written questionnaires, and biomarker assays.

q13.value:
The expected sample size is 10,000 participants; however, neither author has any knowledge of how many participants in the HRS have biomarker data, which is the primary limitation on sample size.

We plan to divide our sample into two cohorts. For the first cohort, we will use their 2010 personality measures and 2010 CESD score (as depression at time one), their 2012 health behavior measures, their 2014 inflammation biomarker data, and their 2016 CESD score as depression at time two. For the second cohort, we will use their 2012 personality measures, 2012 CESD score (as depression at time one), and 2012 inflammation biomarker data, their 2014 health behaviors measures, and their 2018 CESD score as depression at time two.

question.value: NA

BYEAR measures the respondent’s reported birth year.
GENDER measures the respondent's gender.
RACEM measures the respondent's race.
HISPAN measures whether the respondent is Hispanic or not.
EDUC measures the respondent's level of education categorized as "less than high school", "GED", "high-school graduate", "some college", or "college and above". 
MSTAT measures the respondent's marital status, measured as "married", "married, spouse absent", "partnered", "separated", "divorced", "separated/divorced", "widowed", or "never married". 
SHLT measures the respondent’s self-reported general health status scored from 1 "Excellent" to 5 "Poor". 
DEPRES, EFFORT, SLEEPR, WHAPPY, FLONE, FSAD, GOING, and ENLIFE are yes/no indicators of the respondent’s feelings much of the time over the week prior to the interview. CESD is a summary of these measures.
BMI is a continuous measure of the body-mass index of the respondent.
VGACTX is a measure of the respondent's frequency of vigorous physical activity, scored from 1 "every day" to 5 "never".
MDACTX is a measure of the respondent's frequency of moderate physical activity, scored from 1 "every day" to 5 "never".
LTACTX is a measure of the respondent's frequency of light physical activity, scored from 1 "every day" to 5 "never".
DRINKD is a measure of the number of days per week that the respondent drinks alcohol.
DRINKN is a continuous measure of the number of drinks per day that the respondent consumes on days that they drink.
SMOKEN is a measure of whether or not the respondent smokes currently.

Gender, race, if Hispanic, education - "tracker file"

Personality was assessed at least once between 2010 and 2016. We are choosing to ignore the 2006 and 2008 assessments of personality because they did not include the additional conscientiousness items, and reliable measurement of conscientiousness is imperative to the present analyses. For each participant, we will use the first measurement personality starting in 2010 for their scores.

Inflammation was assessed through levels of the C-Reactive Protein biomarker gathered from dried blood spot (DBS) sample assays. We will use the samples gathered in 2012 and 2014.

Conscientiousness and neuroticism will be calculated using sum scores: the average of responses to the C and N items will be averaged, after negatively keyed items are reverse scored.

We plan to multiply DRINKD by DRINKN to create a single variable that describes the participant's average number of drinks per week.

Path analysis will be used to explore the direct and indirect effects of personality on mental health through health behaviors and inflammation.

The primary model will be built as follows:
A participant's first measure of personality and the concurrent measure of depression will be entered as primary predictors. Behavior at the wave following personality measurement will be regressed onto personality; inflammation at the next assessment following behavior will be regressed onto behavior. Finally, the assessment of mental health at or after inflammation will be regressed onto inflammation, personalty, and first mental health assessment.

Additional path models will be specified testing a variety of links between personality, mental health, inflammation, and behavior. Figures representing these models are uploaded.

Models will be tested using the lavaan package.

q20.value: All variables will be coded such that larger numbers indicate better health or healthier behavior. For example, self-rated health is currently coded from 1 "Excellent" to 5 "Poor" and this variable will be reverse-scored prior to analysis.

q21.value:
We will test the statistical significance of direct and indirect pathways using the lavaan package in R with bootstrapped 95% confidence intervals. Confidence intervals excluding 0 will indicate statistical significance. 

We compare model fit using CFI, Gamma hat, and McDonald's NCI. Models which?differ in CFI by at least .01, Gamma Hat by at least .001, or McDonald's NCI by at least .02 will be reported.

q22.value:
Participants must have completed each of the following in order to be included in the analyses:

1. at least one assessment of personality between 2010 and 2016.
2. at least one bio-assay of CRP
3. at least one health behavior assessment following the personality assessment
4. at least two assessments of depression, one concurrent with personality and one following.

We will not exclude outliers, nor are there any awareness checks relevant to the study design.

q23.value: We will use full information maximum likelihood to estimate models.

q24.value: We may choose to look at the relationship between our main study and the variables HNC17, HNC17A, HNC17B, and HNC17CM1 from a 2013 nutrition off-year project in the Health and Retirement Study data set. Since we are unsure of whether this 2013 study used the same participants or if it will fit into our main study, we will treat it as exploratory.

attributes.title: Is racial bias in pain perception evident under minimal exposure conditions?
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value:
1: Presentation speed (7 levels: 33ms, 50ms, 67ms, 100ms, 167ms, 500ms, unconstrained)
(1)	Within-participant
(2)	Orthogonal

question2b.value:
1: Pain ratings (binary judgment: Yes/No)
(1)	For purposes of correlational analyses, “No” responses will be coded as a 0, and “Yes” responses will be coded as a 1.

2: Bias in pain ratings 
(1)	Each Black target has corresponding White target –- e.g., an identical face (in terms of structure) making the same expression, with White (rather than Black) skintone. Bias will be calcculated in two ways: a) at the subject level (by subtracting the average pain rating for Black targets from average pain rating for White targets within each subject), and b) at the target level (by subtracting the Black pain ratings from White pain ratings for each stimulus pair across subjects).

question3b.value: Feeling thermometers representing participants’ blatant dehumanization (Kteily et al., 2015), intergroup contact (adapted from Cloutier et al., 2014), Internal and External Motivation to Respond Without Prejudice (IMS/EMS; Plant & Devine, 1998), and social evaluations of warmth, status, strength, and threat of both Black and White Americans

question10b.value:
a)	Pain rating and treatment task
(1)	Participants will complete a modified paradigm adapted most directly from Experiment 2 in Todorov et al., 2009 (with input from Todorov & Willis, 2006, as well), in which they will see 96 male targets (48 Black, 48 White; created using FaceGen Pro) varying in their expressions.
(2)	As described above, targets’ expressions will vary in pain intensity (0%, 30%, 70%, 100%), and will be paired by race – in other words, a given Black target making a given pain expression at the 70% level will later appear in the same block as White target with identical facial structure making an identical expression.
(3)	Participants will be informed that stimuli will appear at different speeds throughout the task. Presentation speed will be blocked into 7 different blocks. All 96 faces will appear in each block. 
(4)	Each trial will begin with a 500ms fixation cross, followed by a stimulus (Black or White face depicting some level of pain; variable presentation length). The participant’s task is simply to respond to the question “Is this face in pain?” with a Yes or No response (unlimited time window for response). A 1000ms ITI (blank screen) separates each trial.
(5)	The main independent variable (presentation speed) is completely within-subjects. Individual faces are shown in a randomized order within blocks and blocks are shown in a randomized order. 

b)	Following the task, participants will be asked a series of task-specific questions: an open-ended item asking what they thought the study was about, a multiple-choice item assessing their strategy regarding the pain ratings.

c)	Individual difference measures
(1)	Intergroup contact (adapted from Cloutier et al., 2014)
(2)	EMS/IMS (Plant & Devine, 1998)
(3)	Blatant dehumanization (Kteily et al., 2015)
(4)	Social evaluations of various social groups (including Black and White Americans) in terms of warmth, status, strength, and threat

d)	Debriefing 
(1)	Following the completion of individual difference measures, participants will be debriefed.

question5b.value: 100 White participants recruited from the UD psychology subject pool.

question6b.value: This sample size is somewhat heuristically chosen. That said, it is more than double the largest sample size used in Experiment 2 in Todorov et al., 2009, which this design is modeled after. As per G*Power, this size will afford us 80% power to detect an effect of d = .285 in a one-sample t-test (vs. 0, two-tailed; this test will be used to assess whether correlations between ratings made in each presentation speed bin are greater than chance).

question7b.value: Exclusion-related items (see below) will be assessed after the initial data collection, and subsequent batches will be collected as needed to bring the sample to 100.

question8b.value:
a)	Non-differentiation of responses (e.g., the same response on 90% of trials or greater) will result in exclusion from all analyses.
b)	Participants whose answers to an open-ended response item regarding the purpose of the study approximate the interaction between race and speed on thresholds for pain perception will be excluded from all analyses.

question1a.value:
1. We predict a main effect of presentation length on judgments of pain. Specifically, correlations between judgments under time-pressure and unconstrained judgments will increase in strength from 33ms to 500ms. That being said, we also predict that these correlations will essentially plateau in strength by 167ms, and further, that the agreement between speeded and unconstrained judgments will be above chance by 50ms.

2. Similarly, we predict a main effect of presentation length on racial bias in pain perception. Correlations between bias in judgments (e.g., White pain ratings – Black pain ratings, calculated within pairs of stimuli) will increase in strength with additional presentation time, but again, a) these correlations will plateau in strength by 167ms, and b) will be apparent already by 50ms.

question3a.value: Our stimulus manipulations (e.g., race – black or white; expression – pain or neutral) are clear and strong, and have been extensively piloted in both cases. As such, no manipulation check is needed. Our presentation speed manipulation and masking procedure have also been validated and tested in previous work (e.g., Todorov et al., 2009; Todorov & Willis, 2006).

question5a.value: Recent work demonstrated that racial bias in pain care stems, at least in part, from a perceptual source (Mende-Siedlecki et al., 2019). Racial bias in pain perception arises from disruptions in configural face processing, cannot be explained by low-level stimulus features, persists even when identical expressions of pain are rendered on computer-generated targets, and predicts biases in treatment above and beyond explicit stereotypes and prejudice. That said, the speed with which painful expressions are processed is somewhat unclear, and further, the automaticity of this bias is as of yet uncertain. Are differences in evaluations of Black and White facial expressions of pain evident under minimal presentation conditions, or does this bias require more time (and deliberation) to emerge?

question1c.value: We predict a main effect of presentation length on overall judgments of pain. That said, we predict that a positive correlation between speeded and unconstrained judgments of pain will be detectable above chance by 50ms.

question2c.value: This prediction will be tested as in Todorov et al. (2009) by fitting the correlation within each presentation speed bin to a sigmoid function to assess how much variance is accounted for. As in Todorov et al. (2009), this will be assessed both a) for mean judgments averaged across participants (via bivariate correlation between speeded and unconstrained judgments of pain, with targets as the unit of analysis) and b) within individual participants (e.g., participant-level correlations will be fisher-transformed, averaged, and compared against 0 in a series of one-sample t-tests, two-tailed). Differences between presentation speed time bins will be assessed in the second analysis with paired t-tests.

question3c.value:
IV: Presentation speed (33ms, 50ms, 67ms, 100ms, 167ms, 500ms, unconstrained)
DV: Pain ratings (binary judgments: Yes/No)

question1c.value: We predict a main effect of presentation length on racial bias in pain perception. That said, we predict that a positive correlation between racial bias in pain ratings within speeded and unconstrained judgments will be detectable above chance by 50ms.

question2c.value: This prediction will be tested as in Todorov et al. (2009) by fitting the correlation within each presentation speed bin to a sigmoid function to assess how much variance is accounted for. As in Todorov et al. (2009), this will be assessed both a) for mean judgments averaged across participants (via bivariate correlation between speeded and unconstrained judgments of pain with targets as the unit of analysis) and b) within individual participants (e.g., participant-level correlations will be Fisher-transformed, averaged, and compared against 0 in a series of one-sample t-tests, two-tailed). Differences between presentation speed time bins will be assessed in the second analysis with paired t-tests.

question3c.value:
IV: Presentation length (33ms, 50ms, 67ms, 100ms, 167ms, 500ms, unconstrained)
DV: Racial bias in pain ratings (White minus Black ratings, within pairs)

registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: 100 White participants recruited from the UD psychology subject pool.

This sample size is somewhat heuristically chosen. That said, it is more than double the largest sample size used in Experiment 2 in Todorov et al., 2009, which this design is modeled after. As per G*Power, this size will afford us 80% power to detect an effect of d = .285 in a one-sample t-test (vs. 0, two-tailed; this test will be used to assess whether correlations between ratings made in each presentation speed bin are greater than chance).
Exclusion-related items (see below) will be assessed after the initial data collection, and subsequent batches will be collected as needed to bring the sample to 100.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-second.second.ques: We predict a main effect of presentation length on racial bias in pain perception. That said, we predict that a positive correlation between racial bias in pain ratings within speeded and unconstrained judgments will be detectable above chance by 50ms.

This prediction will be tested as in Todorov et al. (2009) by fitting the correlation within each presentation speed bin to a sigmoid function to assess how much variance is accounted for. As in Todorov et al. (2009), this will be assessed both a) for mean judgments averaged across participants (via bivariate correlation between speeded and unconstrained judgments of pain with targets as the unit of analysis) and b) within individual participants (e.g., participant-level correlations will be Fisher-transformed, averaged, and compared against 0 in a series of one-sample t-tests, two-tailed). Differences between presentation speed time bins will be assessed in the second analysis with paired t-tests.

IV: Presentation length (33ms, 50ms, 67ms, 100ms, 167ms, 500ms, unconstrained)
DV: Racial bias in pain ratings (White minus Black ratings, within pairs)
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
a)	Non-differentiation of responses (e.g., the same response on 90% of trials or greater) will result in exclusion from all analyses.
b)	Participants whose answers to an open-ended response item regarding the purpose of the study approximate the interaction between race and speed on thresholds for pain perception will be excluded from all analyses.
